descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course provides a survey of the fundamentals of marketing within an innovative customer-value framework. We evaluate major trends and forces impacting marketing in the era of customer value and high-tech customer relationships: customer engagement marketing; a deep focus on brands; integrated marketing principles; and marketing accountability/measuring and managing return. Students will develop an understanding of how marketing is defined, marketing strategy (including segmentation, targeting and positioning), the macro-marketing environment, customer insights, consumer behavior, building customer value with brands, the four Ps (product, pricing, place and promotion), and the increasing importance of social responsibility.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
At the end of this course, students will be able to:
? Recognize and define fundamental marketing terminology
? Verbalize and apply the relationships between the four core elements of the marketing mix: Product, Price, Promotion, and Distribution (Placement)
? Apply a marketing orientation to business problems in order to create effective marketing strategies and tactics across the product life cycle
? Divide potential consumers into market segments
? Identify best target segments based on the marketing environment, competitor behavior, industry trends, and consumer preferences
? Describe the varied approaches to building brand and customer equity

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Presentations, case studies, class discussion of text reading and supplemental articles, videos, guest speakers, online work, team projects (case studies), individual preparation/assignments

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Homework assignments, case study analyses, quizzes and final exam, class attendance and participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Texts and materials will include Principles of Marketing, Kotler and Armstrong (14th, 15th, or 16th edition), case studies packet, and select articles (provided via Canvas).
